description.narrative: Deriving Data to Design Better and More Inclusive Social Services for Persons with Disabilities

comment.narrative:
Deriving Data to Design Better Services for Persons with Disabilities This programme immanently contributes to promotion and implementation of the recommendations set with the UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities. Two field surveys done in 2016 have been promoted in 2017 enabling people with disabilities and their families to express their concerns regarding lack of services on a local level. Collection of data focused on people with disabilities has been organized in several modules in three regions in the country, involving 600 persons with disabilities and respondents from almost all foster families. Through the project, UNDP has provided work-oriented rehabilitation services for 23 people with disabilities currently based in the Banja Bansko Protection Institute (located in the South-East Region). These services included a capacity assessment and provision of tailored psycho-social and training support to improve skills and promote labour market inclusion, and are based on EU good practices. For this purpose, three workshops have been organized with 15 professionals from different institutions and NGOs, on the process and the structure of work-oriented rehabilitation process. The programme fosters partnership with the civil society organizations, in particular related to the anticipated intensive field work with the beneficiaries. End-beneficiaries are actively involved in designing the approach to better reach this vulnerable group and to share best practices from this intervention. Organizations and associations of people with disabilities shall be also involved in designing workable models for economic inclusion of people with disabilities.
Data on roots and manifestations of the specific attitudes of men towards paid and non-paid social care services UNDP social inclusion programme initiated interventions that aim at mapping the social care services through gender-sensitive lens and explore men’s attitudes and practices in the areas of paid and unpaid social care services. By unique focus on the factors that may lead to improved men’s role in the social care services, the survey data will also aim to promote increased women’s role in paid work and more meaningful and targeted use of women’s free time. Future interventions will build on the findings of this research by cross-examining the attitude of men in relation to social care services.

Deriving Data to Design Better Services for Persons with Disabilities This programme immanently contributes to promotion and implementation of the recommendations set with the UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities. Two field surveys done in 2016 have been promoted in 2017 enabling people with disabilities and their families to express their concerns regarding lack of services on a local level. Collection of data focused on people with disabilities has been organized in several modules in three regions in the country, involving 600 persons with disabilities and respondents from almost all foster families. Through the project, UNDP has provided work-oriented rehabilitation services for 23 people with disabilities currently based in the Banja Bansko Protection Institute (located in the South-East Region). These services included a capacity assessment and provision of tailored psycho-social and training support to improve skills and promote labour market inclusion, and are based on EU good practices. For this purpose, three workshops have been organized with 15 professionals from different institutions and NGOs, on the process and the structure of work-oriented rehabilitation process. The programme fosters partnership with the civil society organizations, in particular related to the anticipated intensive field work with the beneficiaries. End-beneficiaries are actively involved in designing the approach to better reach this vulnerable group and to share best practices from this intervention. Organizations and associations of people with disabilities shall be also involved in designing workable models for economic inclusion of people with disabilities.
Data on roots and manifestations of the specific attitudes of men towards paid and non-paid social care services UNDP social inclusion programme initiated interventions that aim at mapping the social care services through gender-sensitive lens and explore men’s attitudes and practices in the areas of paid and unpaid social care services. By unique focus on the factors that may lead to improved men’s role in the social care services, the survey data will also aim to promote increased women’s role in paid work and more meaningful and targeted use of women’s free time. Future interventions will build on the findings of this research by cross-examining the attitude of men in relation to social care services.

- Two field surveys on the needs of persons with disabilities and quality of life and services of persons with disabilitiesplaced in foster families carried out; - First training session to 15 professionals carried out;

Two surveys have been carried out, one focused on biological and the other on foster families, to understand better the capabilities as well as the barriers for their integration at the labour market. 590 families with members that have disabilities and 91 foster families have successfully filled in our survey, by the end of Dec '16. Results will be available by the end of Feb '17. Through mapathon initiative UNDP piloted mapping of physical barriers in the city of Negotino. The intervention will continue to cover app 30 cities in the country during the first Q of this year. Work oriented rehabilitation training has been initiated to prepare professionals to gain the knowledge on how to assess people abilities and increase their capabilities for higher engagement in the labor market and in the society. Additionally, one-day workshop was organized for professionals working in 3 institutions in the country, to discuss the barriers towards deinstitutionalization process in the country.

- Two field surveys on the needs of persons with disabilities and quality of life and services of persons with disabilitiesplaced in foster families carried out; - First training session to 15 professionals carried out;

Two surveys have been carried out, one focused on biological and the other on foster families, to understand better the capabilities as well as the barriers for their integration at the labour market. 590 families with members that have disabilities and 91 foster families have successfully filled in our survey, by the end of Dec '16. Results will be available by the end of Feb '17. Through mapathon initiative UNDP piloted mapping of physical barriers in the city of Negotino. The intervention will continue to cover app 30 cities in the country during the first Q of this year. Work oriented rehabilitation training has been initiated to prepare professionals to gain the knowledge on how to assess people abilities and increase their capabilities for higher engagement in the labor market and in the society. Additionally, one-day workshop was organized for professionals working in 3 institutions in the country, to discuss the barriers towards deinstitutionalization process in the country.
